unnormalised: The Indian Income Tax Act, 1961, is the primary legislation governing income tax in India. It levies tax on various sources of income. Amendments are frequently made via the Finance Act each year, keeping up with economic changes. Understanding key sections is crucial for compliance.
normalised: The Indian Income Tax Act, one thousand nine hundred and sixty one, is the primary legislation governing income tax in India. It levies tax on various sources of income. Amendments are frequently made via the Finance Act each year, keeping up with economic changes. Understanding key sections is crucial for compliance.

unnormalised: Section 80C allows deductions up to Rs. 1.5 lakh for investments like PPF, LIC, and ELSS. These investments help reduce taxable income significantly. Claiming these deductions requires proper documentation.
normalised: Section eighty C allows deductions up to rupee one point five lakh for investments like P-P-F, L-I-C, and E-L-S-S. These investments help reduce taxable income significantly. Claiming these deductions requires proper documentation.

unnormalised: Goods and Services Tax (GST), implemented on 01/07/2017, replaced many indirect taxes. It simplified the tax structure with multiple tax slabs. Businesses with turnover exceeding Rs. 40 lakh (Rs. 20 lakh for special category states) must register under GST. Input Tax Credit (ITC) allows businesses to offset tax paid on purchases against tax on sales.
normalised: Goods and Services Tax (G-S-T), implemented on first July two thousand and seventeen, replaced many indirect taxes. It simplified the tax structure with multiple tax slabs. Businesses with turnover exceeding rupee forty lakh (rupee twenty lakh for special category states) must register under G-S-T. Input Tax Credit (I-T-C) allows businesses to offset tax paid on purchases against tax on sales.

unnormalised: Taxpayers need to file income tax returns (ITR) by the due dates. For individuals, the due date is typically 31st July unless extended. Late filing attracts penalties under Section 234F. Different ITR forms are applicable based on income source. For instance, ITR-1 is for salaried individuals, while ITR-3 is for business income.
normalised: Taxpayers need to file income tax returns (I-T-R) by the due dates. For individuals, the due date is typically thirty first July unless extended. Late filing attracts penalties under Section two hundred and thirty four F. Different I-T-R forms are applicable based on income source. For instance, I-T-R one is for salaried individuals, while I-T-R three is for business income.

unnormalised: Advance tax must be paid if tax liability exceeds Rs. 10,000 in a financial year. This is usually paid in quarterly installments. Senior citizens are exempt from advance tax under certain conditions.
normalised: Advance tax must be paid if tax liability exceeds rupee ten thousand in a financial year. This is usually paid in quarterly installments. Senior citizens are exempt from advance tax under certain conditions.

unnormalised: Tax evasion is illegal and attracts penalties and prosecution. The Income Tax Department conducts regular audits and raids to detect tax evasion. Reporting suspicious transactions under Section 285BA is mandatory for certain entities.
normalised: Tax evasion is illegal and attracts penalties and prosecution. The Income Tax Department conducts regular audits and raids to detect tax evasion. Reporting suspicious transactions under Section two hundred and eighty five B-A is mandatory for certain entities.

unnormalised: Double Taxation Avoidance Agreements (DTAA) prevent individuals and companies from being taxed twice on the same income. India has DTAAs with numerous countries. These agreements usually provide for lower tax rates.
normalised: Double Taxation Avoidance Agreements (D-T-A-A) prevent individuals and companies from being taxed twice on the same income. India has D-T-A-As with numerous countries. These agreements usually provide for lower tax rates.

unnormalised: Recent amendments have focused on digital transactions and cryptocurrency taxation. A TDS of 1% is applicable on virtual digital assets (VDAs). These changes reflect the government's efforts to broaden the tax base.
normalised: Recent amendments have focused on digital transactions and cryptocurrency taxation. A T-D-S of one percent is applicable on virtual digital assets (V-D-A-s). These changes reflect the government's efforts to broaden the tax base.
